item.content:encoded: Abstract submissions open tomorrow! üö® üîé Let‚Äôs review some key rules and guidelines for submission. #SfN23 #neurotwitter #phdchat #phdlife

item.title:
1. Your research must be original üß†.
At the time of submission your research should not have been previously published, verbatim, as a scientific article or meeting abstract.
item.description:
1. Your research must be original üß†.
At the time of submission your research should not have been previously published, verbatim, as a scientific article or meeting abstract.
item.content:encoded: 1. Your research must be original üß†. At the time of submission your research should not have been previously published, verbatim, as a scientific article or meeting abstract.

item.title:
2. Report relevant biological variables & include data üß™!
It is not satisfactory to say, "The results will be discussed." Emphasize the rationale, significance of results, and general principles.
item.description:
2. Report relevant biological variables & include data üß™!
It is not satisfactory to say, "The results will be discussed." Emphasize the rationale, significance of results, and general principles.
item.content:encoded: 2. Report relevant biological variables & include data üß™! It is not satisfactory to say, "The results will be discussed." Emphasize the rationale, significance of results, and general principles.

item.title:
3. Don‚Äôt forget about rigor üî¨!
Summarize your efforts to ensure scientific rigor. For example, include sample size and replication, blinding, and which controls were used in your study.

item.title:
1/4) Several people I admire immensely have signed this, but respectfully, I'm afraid I just don't agree with the claim that "mitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority".
I think this statement is naive and a mistake. https://t.co/ahrJ8ZIa6a
item.description:
1/4) Several people I admire immensely have signed this, but respectfully, I'm afraid I just don't agree with the claim that "mitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority".
I think this statement is naive and a mistake. https://t.co/ahrJ8ZIa6a
item.content:encoded: 1/4) Several people I admire immensely have signed this, but respectfully, I'm afraid I just don't agree with the claim that "mitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority". I think this statement is naive and a mistake. https://t.co/ahrJ8ZIa6a

item.title: 2/4) Compared to other global risks (e.g. climate change, war between the US/China, and the breakdown of democracy) the extinction risk from AI is purely hypothetical, and not an imminent danger. We have many more important things we should be spending our time talking about.
item.description: 2/4) Compared to other global risks (e.g. climate change, war between the US/China, and the breakdown of democracy) the extinction risk from AI is purely hypothetical, and not an imminent danger. We have many more important things we should be spending our time talking about.
item.content:encoded: 2/4) Compared to other global risks (e.g. climate change, war between the US/China, and the breakdown of democracy) the extinction risk from AI is purely hypothetical, and not an imminent danger. We have many more important things we should be spending our time talking about.

item.title:
3/4) Moreover, we risk overlooking real immediate threats from AI (e.g. use of AI for manipulating populations, biased models being used to make decisions, etc.).
And, we risk impairing research into beneficial applications of AI with this sort of hyperbole.
item.description:
3/4) Moreover, we risk overlooking real immediate threats from AI (e.g. use of AI for manipulating populations, biased models being used to make decisions, etc.).
And, we risk impairing research into beneficial applications of AI with this sort of hyperbole.
item.content:encoded: 3/4) Moreover, we risk overlooking real immediate threats from AI (e.g. use of AI for manipulating populations, biased models being used to make decisions, etc.). And, we risk impairing research into beneficial applications of AI with this sort of hyperbole.

item.title:
4/4) To be clear, I'm not saying there is *zero* risk. Rather, the risk is so hypothetical that it should be on the back-burner relative to more pressing issues.
In other words, it shouldn't be a *priority*, as the statement says.
We have more important stuff to worry about.
